questions.text: Which of the following is the manifestation of increased estrogen levels in Cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Palmar erythema

 

Explanation:

Increased estrogen levels in chronic liver failure lead to vascular changes, resulting in palmar erythema and spider angiomas. This condition can also cause hypogonadism and gynecomastia in males.


 

Increased PT and aPTT (Option A) are primarily due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors by the damaged liver rather than the effects of hyperestrogenemia.


Flapping tremors (aka asterixis) (Option B) are commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy in cirrhosis, primarily due to elevated ammonia levels rather than estrogen.

 

Jaundice (Option D) seen in cirrhosis is a result of impaired bilirubin metabolism due to liver dysfunction rather than being directly influenced by estrogen levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with developing fatty liver disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis B

 

Explanation:

  • Hepatitis B primarily affects the liver by causing inflammation and can lead to chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and liver cancer, but it does not directly cause fatty liver disease.
  • Fatty liver disease is often associated with several factors, such as alcoholism (Option D), obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes (Option C).
  • Chronic Hepatitis C (Option B) can cause liver inflammation and damage, potentially resulting in fat accumulation in the liver cells and leading to fatty liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically observed in liver biopsy findings of acute hepatitis A infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Councilman bodies

 

Explanation:

Councilman bodies, also known as acidophilic or apoptotic bodies, are eosinophilic structures representing apoptotic hepatocytes. These are characteristic findings of acute viral hepatitis.

 

Biopsy findings of acute viral hepatitis

  • Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes
  • Councilman bodies
  • Spotty necrosis
  • Dropout necrosis and Kupffer cell hyperplasia (Empty space lined by Kupffer cells)
  • Absent or mild portal inflammation



 

Interface hepatitis (Option A) is characterised by inflammatory cell infiltrates at the interface between the portal tracts and hepatic lobules and is prominent in Chronic viral hepatitis rather than acute.

 

Ground glass hepatocytes (Option C) (aka Shikata cells) are densely eosinophilic cells with glassy cytoplasm due to HBsAg. They are seen in chronic Hepatitis B infection but not acute hepatitis.

 

Bridging fibrosis (Option D) refers to fibrous septa or thick collagenous bands connecting adjacent portal tracts and central veins. It is typically observed in Chronic hepatitis and is indicative of advanced liver fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the most likely autoantibody detected in Type I autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA)

Explanation:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by the presence of autoantibodies targeting various liver antigens.
  • In Type 1 AIH, the most commonly detected autoantibody is anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA), which target actin filaments in the smooth muscle cells of blood vessels and the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following changes is reversible with alcohol abstinence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perivenular fibrosis

 

Explanation:

  • In the early stages of alcoholic liver disease, fibrosis typically begins around the central veins (central venules) in the liver lobules (perivenular or centrilobular zone) with a characteristic "chicken wire" appearance.
  • With cessation of alcohol intake and appropriate treatment, this perivenular or pericellular fibrosis can regress, leading to improvement in liver function and histology.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with Mallory-Denk bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemochromatosis

Explanation: Among the given options, Hemochromatosis is not associated with Mallory-Denk bodies.

Mallory-Denk bodies are seen in:

  1. Alcoholic liver disease (ALD)
  2. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
  3. Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) (Option C)
  4. Wilson's disease (Option A)
  5. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option D)
  6. Hepatocellular carcinoma
  7. Cholestasis
  8. Hepatic or primary biliary diseases.

 

 

Mallory-Denk bodies are not seen in:

  1. Hemochromatosis (Option B)
  2. Secondary biliary diseases.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss. A biopsy of the liver was done. Which of the following histopathological features is characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Denk bodies

Explanation: The histopathological feature characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image is Mallory-Denk bodies, a hallmark of both alcohol-induced and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

  • These are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions seen in hepatocytes.
  • They comprise intermediate filaments, primarily cytokeratin 8 and 18, and other proteins like ubiquitin.
  • They indicate cellular injury and are often associated with hepatocyte ballooning and inflammation.

 

Mallory - Denk bodies are also seen in (New Indian WATCH)

  • Non alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Tumors like hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Chronic cholestasis
  • Focal nodular Hyperplasia


 

Ground-glass hepatocytes (Option B):

This morphological change is seen in chronic hepatitis B infection, where hepatocytes display a granular, homogenous eosinophilic cytoplasm due to the accumulation of HBsAg in the swollen smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

 

 

Councilman bodies (Option C):

Councilman bodies (or acidophilic bodies) are eosinophilic, round structures representing hepatocyte apoptosis. They are typically seen in acute viral hepatitis and indicate severe hepatocellular injury.

 

 

Glycogenated hepatocytes (Option D):

  • Glycogenated hepatocytes are hepatocytes with increased intracytoplasmic glycogen content.
  • This finding is often seen in conditions associated with metabolic disturbances, such as glycogen storage diseases or acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal distension and jaundice. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab tests show elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin levels. Imaging shows nodules <3mm throughout the liver. Which of the following conditions can present with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemochromatosis

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests micronodular liver cirrhosis with nodules  <3mm.

Hemochromatosis is one of the causes of micronodular cirrhosis.

questions.text: Which cells are primarily involved in the fibrosis in liver cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stellate cells

Explanation:

  • Hepatic stellate cells (or Ito cells) are pericytes located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver.
  • In the healthy liver, these cells store vitamin A in lipid droplets and regulate sinusoidal blood flow.
  • Upon liver injury, they activate and transform into myofibroblast-like cells, release TGFβ, and lead to fibrosis by producing excessive extracellular matrix, such as collagen.


 

Kupffer cells (Option A) are macrophages found in sinusoids of the liver, involved in phagocytosis.

 

Pit cells (Option B) are liver-associated lymphocytes, primarily NK (Natural Killer) cells. They contribute to liver immune surveillance but are not directly implicated in liver fibrosis.

 

Hepatocytes (Option D) are vital liver cells.

questions.text: Which of the following stains would be most useful for highlighting collagen deposition in the fibrotic areas of the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Masson's trichrome stain

 

Explanation:

Masson's trichrome stain is commonly used to visualize collagen fibers, making it suitable for highlighting fibrotic areas in liver tissue.

questions.text: Which type of collagen is predominantly involved in the fibrotic process of cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Collagen Type I and III

 

Explanation: The fibrotic process in cirrhosis primarily involves activating hepatic stellate cells, leading to collagen deposition by myofibroblasts. These cells predominantly produce Collagen Types I and III.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic jaundice and mild abdominal discomfort. Examination revealed hepatomegaly. Lab tests indicate elevated levels of direct bilirubin. Upon liver biopsy, a pigmented liver is observed. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for these clinical and pathological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRP2 (Multidrug resistance-associated protein 2) defect

 

Explanation:

The clinical and pathological findings are consistent with Dubin-Johnson syndrome, which is characterised by impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile due to a defect in the MRP2 transporter leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

The characteristic pigmented liver is due to the accumulation of epinephrine metabolite (not bilirubin).

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice since birth and markedly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels (>20 mg/dL) despite exposure to sunlight. Genetic testing confirms homozygosity for a specific mutation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the provided scenario, the likely diagnosis is Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1, a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterised by the complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 1A1 (UGT1A1), leading to severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Without treatment, this condition can progress to kernicterus, a potentially fatal neurologic complication due to bilirubin deposition in the brain.
  • It is 100% fatal if left untreated.

questions.text: Which change can be seen in a structure that connects hepatocytes with cholangiocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Liver regeneration

 

Explanation:

  • The structure connecting hepatocytes with cholangiocytes is the Canals of Hering.
  • It contains oval cells (aka liver stem cells), which play a pivotal role in liver regeneration. Therefore, changes observed in this structure are related to liver regeneration.

questions.text: Which zone of the liver lobule is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zone 3 (perivenous zone)

 

Explanation:

Zone 3 (perivenous or pericentral) is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism because Zone 3 hepatocytes are close to the central vein and have the highest levels of cytochrome P450 enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not typically involved in promoting fibrogenesis and hepatic stellate cell activation in chronic liver diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interleukin-10 (IL-10)

Explanation:

 

Factors

Role in hepatic pathology

Interleukin 10 (Option C)
  • Antiinflammatory
  • Inhibits hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Reduces fibrogenesis by counteracting pro-inflammatory cytokines

Interleukin 6 (Option A)
  • Pro-inflammatory
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes fibrogenesis and inflammation in chronic liver diseases
  • Associated with hepatic regeneration

Platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) (Option B)
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes proliferation and migration of HSC to site of injury
  • Contributes to fibrogenesis

Transforming growth factor - β (TGF-β) (Option D)
  • Promotes profibrotic cytokines in liver diseases
  • Stimulates HSC activation and transformation into myofibroblast
  • Enhances Extracellular Matrix production and inhibits ECM degradation
